text:
Bogue is a city in Graham County, Kansas, United States. In 2010, 143 people lived there.
History.
Bogue was created in 1888 as a railroad town. It originally was named Wild Horse but the Union Pacific Railroad changed the name to honor Virgil Gay Bogue, a civil engineer working for the railroad and the founder of the city.
The first post office in Bogue was created in September 1888. It was moved from Fagan.
Geography.
Bogue is at (39.359648, −99.688282). The United States Census Bureau says that the city has a total area of. All of it is land.
Bogue is on K-18. It is south of U.S. Route 24, on the South Fork Solomon River.
Climate.
Bogue has hot, humid summers and generally mild to cool winters. The Köppen Climate Classification system says that Bogue has a humid subtropical climate, abbreviated "Cfa" on climate maps.
2010 census.
The 2010 census says that there were 143 people, 75 households, and 43 families living in Bogue.
Education.
Bogue is a part of USD 281 Graham County. The district high school is in Hill City.
